0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Extraction of cataract - Inflammatory disorder of the eye - Pain: (0.3% suspension) 1 drop in affected eye once daily starting 1 day prior to surgery, the day of surgery, and continuing through the first 2 weeks postoperatively; apply 1 additional drop 30 to 120 minutes prior to surgery
  • Extraction of cataract - Inflammatory disorder of the eye - Pain: (0.1% suspension) 1 drop in affected eye 3 times a day starting 1 day prior to surgery, continued on the day of surgery, and through the first 2 weeks of the postoperative period

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• Extraction of cataract - Inflammatory disorder of the eye - Pain: (0.3% suspension) 10 years or older, 1 drop in affected eye once daily starting 1 day prior to surgery, the day of surgery, and continuing through the first 2 weeks postoperatively; apply 1 additional drop 30 to 120 minutes prior to surgery
  • Extraction of cataract - Inflammatory disorder of the eye - Pain: (0.1% suspension) 10 years or older, 1 drop in affected eye 3 times a day starting 1 day prior to surgery, continued on the day of surgery, and through the first 2 weeks of the postoperative period

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Extraction of cataract - Inflammatory disorder of the eye - Pain

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: Prior hypersensitivity to nepafenac, any product component, or other NSAIDs

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Endocrine Metabolic:
  • -- Diabetes mellitus; increased risk for sight-threatening corneal adverse events
  • Hematologic:
  • -- Use may increase bleeding time, especially in patients with bleeding tendencies or receiving concomitant medications that can prolong bleeding
  • Immunologic:
  • -- Rheumatoid arthritis; increased risk for sight-threatening corneal adverse events
  • Ophthalmic:
  • -- Increased bleeding in ocular tissues, including hyphema, may occur with NSAID instillation in conjunction with ocular surgery
  • -- Keratitis may develop with use of topical NSAIDs
  • -- Sight-threatening epithelial breakdown and corneal thinning, erosion, ulceration, or perforation may occur, especially with prolonged use (ie, more than 1 day before surgery or more than 14 days post-op); immediately discontinue if corneal epithelial breakdown develops
  • -- Increased risk of sight-threatening corneal adverse events among patients with a history of complicated or repeated ocular surgeries, corneal denervation, corneal epithelial defects, dry eye syndrome, or other ocular surface conditions
  • Other:
  • -- Delayed healing may occur
  • -- Do not instill in patients wearing contact lenses

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
Ophthalmic:Discharge from eye (5% to 10%), Disorder of lens capsule (5% to 10%), Foreign body sensation (5% to 10%), Raised intraocular pressure (5% to 10%), Reduced visual acuity (5% to 10%)
Serious
  • Immunologic:Impaired wound healing
  • Ophthalmic:Corneal erosion, Corneal thinning, Corneal ulcer, Hyphema, Intraocular hemorrhage, Keratitis, Perforation of cornea, Vitreous detachment (1% to 5%)

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Tmax, 0.1% ophthalmic suspension: 3 hours (amfenac); 2 hours (nepafenac)
  • Tmax, 0.3% ophthalmic suspension: 0.75 hours (amfenac): 0.5 hours (nepafenac)

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Ophthalmic
  • Shake well before instillation
  • Do not administer while wearing contact lenses
  • Administer concomitant ophthalmic drugs at least 5 minutes apart

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono: Reduced pain and inflammation associated with cataract surgery is indicative of efficacy.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• This drug may cause reduced visual acuity, conjunctival edema, or dryness, foreign body sensation, itching, photophobia, or hyperemia of the eye. Drug may also cause vitreous detachment or delayed healing.
  • Instruct patients using more than one ophthalmic medication to administer at least 5 minutes apart.
  • Instruct patient on proper instillation technique.
  • Patient should not administer drug while wearing contact lenses.
  • Advise patient to not use drug more than 14 days post-surgery, unless approved by healthcare professional, as this increases risk for adverse corneal effects.
  • Patient should not use aspirin or other NSAIDs while taking this drug, as these may prolong bleeding time.
  • Tell patient to avoid using topical forms of steroids or other NSAIDs, as these may cause delayed healing.
